abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Kenya Development
            Learning Center (KDLC) Project for Kenya were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the first
            lesson learned is that a more careful assessment of the
            conditions on the ground should have been carried out and
            considered during the design phase. The Kenya DLC was under
            designed with respect to prevailing needs. The
            one-size-fits-all approach to capacity and construction
            design that was used for all other DLCs was unsuitable for
            the Kenya context, and proved inappropriate, especially
            since this was an innovative project. Another lesson learned
            is that the borrower should have been allowed to continue
            using its own designed Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E)
            module and the Bank task management team should have been
            more hands-on with the client's M&E module by
            evaluating and providing direction on the indicators. This
            will have saved time on both sides. Bank management could
            also have assigned an Information Solutions Group (ISG)
            expert to be based in the country office to work with the
            Government in implementing the project or at least provided
            adequate supervision resources to enable local hire of the
            desired expertise. The Bank could have been more proactive
            in engaging with the KDLC and in using its services to
            support the implementation of operations, through the use of
            the different ICT tools provided by the Center and to
            promote South-South knowledge exchanges.

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Development Learning Center Project
            : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Development
            Learning Center Project for Kenya aims to improve the
            capacity of public servants, private individuals and
            institutions in specific public sector management areas
            targeted by the development learning center (DLC). The
            project supports the Kenya Development Learning Center
            (KDLC), a Global Development Learning Network (GDLN) center,
            through a SDR 2 million International Development
            Association (IDA) grant approved on October 17, 2003 and
            declared effective on February 2, 2004. The project faced
            implementation delays during the construction phase at the
            very beginning of the project implementation. Since the
            completion of component one (construction and establishment
            of the center), the implementation has been moving forward
            as planned, although with a two year delay. Following the
            recommendation from the mid-term review, and in order to
            re-align the project objectives with the regional GDLN
            program ones, the project was restructured on October 19,
            2007 and extended to June 30, 2010.

display_title.display_title:
Kenya - Development Learning
            Center Project : restructuring : Main report

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Development Learning Centre Project
            : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
This Project Paper seeks the approval of
            Bank management to amend the Kenya Development Learning
            Centre Project as requested by government on July 16,
            2007The proposed changes are as follows: (i) modify the
            Project Development Objective (PDO) to better articulate the
            project's specific intention, scope and results. Thus,
            the revised PDO will read as follows: "to improve the
            capacity of public servants, and private individuals and
            institutions in specific public sector management areas
            targeted by the development learning centre"; (ii)
            revise the results framework indicators to improve alignment
            with the proposed PDO and attribution to Project activities;
            (iii) specify the project years eligible under IDA'S
            decreasing financing for operating costs, Part B, category
            4(b), as follows: 80 percent up to June 30, 2008; 60 percent
            from July 1, 2008 to June 30, 2009; and 40 percent
            thereafter; and (iv)  extend the closing date of the project
            by 18 months from December 31, 2008 to June 30, 2010, in
            order to allow sufficient time to achieve the Project's
            objective. This package of measures will help improve the
            implementation of the Project and help the government to
            take advantage of emerging new programs that require
            considerable capacity development in the public sector.

abstracts.cdata!:
The main purpose of the Development
            Learning Centre Project is to test the effectiveness, and
            sustainability of a development learning centre (DLC) in
            Kenya, as part of a global knowledge-sharing network to
            strengthen the capacity of public, private, and civil
            society decision makers, and implementers in designing,
            planning, and managing social, and economic development
            policies, and programs. The first component, construction
            and installation, entails setting up the DLC's
            institutional, physical, and human resources requirements,
            during the first year of the project, and prior to the start
            up of the DLC's operations (year 2-5). The Directorate
            of Personnel Management (DPM), Office of the President, is
            responsible for implementing this component under the
            leadership of a Project Coordinator. Construction of the DLC
            facility includes a video-conference room, computer room, a
            technical, and administrative center, as well as
            electrical/telephone installations. Additionally, equipment
            for a small aperture terminal VSAT satellite communication
            terminal, telecommunications, and microprocessor equipment
            will be supplied. The second component will assist DLC
            operations, and its financial viability, i.e., financing
            operational costs on a decreasing basis over the first four
            years of operation. Institutional arrangements will be
            established for the daily management of the DLC, with
            particular attention to the interaction between DPM and the
            DLC. This will become paramount in the preparation of a
            business plan, based on a market study, that identifies
            training needs, and capacity building, and, for the
            development of a monitoring and evaluation (M&E) plan,
            to be submitted on annual, and quarterly basis. The third
            component will finance the processes involved in M&E
            training, and development plan, supported by consultants
            whose aim will be to promote an external independent
            assessment outside DLC.
